contextId.information: The speaker speaks as if a "word" were a physical object that someone could bring. AT: "told us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: brought us word and said

contextId.information: The writer speaks as if the ability to rest were a physical object that could be given as a gift. The word "rest" is also a metaphor for peaceful life in which there is no war. AT: "Yahweh allows your brothers to rest" or "Yahweh allows your brothers to stop fighting wars and live peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh gives rest to your brothers

contextId.information: The writer speaks as if trusting in Yahweh and obeying him were like physically holding on to a person. AT: "you who were careful to obey Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you who clung to Yahweh

contextId.information: Moses compares how Yahweh acts when he is angry to the way a fire destroys things. AT: "Yahweh your God will severely punish and destroy you like a fire does because he does not want you to worship other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh your God is a devouring fire, a jealous God

contextId.information: Moses speaks as if the people were seeds that Yahweh would scatter around a field. AT: "Yahweh will send you to many different places and force you to live there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will scatter you among the peoples

contextId.information: Here "a mighty hand" and "an outstretched arm" are metaphors for Yahweh's power. AT: "and by showing his mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and by a mighty hand, and by an outstretched arm

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. AT: "be able to live a long time." Translate these words as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: prolong your days

contextId.information: Here "a mighty hand" and "an outstretched arm" are metaphors for Yahweh's power. Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. AT: "by showing his mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: by a mighty hand and by an outstretched arm

contextId.information: This compares a person disobeying God to a person turning off of the correct path. AT: "you will not disobey him in any way" or "you will do everything he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will not turn aside to the right hand or to the left

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. This can be stated in active form. This can be translated similarly to "prolong your days" in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. AT: "that I may prolong your days" or "that I may cause you to live a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: that your days may be prolonged

contextId.information: Moses compares Yahweh's anger to someone starting a fire. This emphasizes Yahweh's power to destroy what makes him angry. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will kindle his anger against you" or "Then Yahweh will become very angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: So the anger of Yahweh will be kindled against you

contextId.information: Yahweh choosing the people of Israel to belong to him in a special way is spoken of as if Yahweh set them apart from all other nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are a nation that is set apart

contextId.information: Here "a mighty hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "with his mighty power." These words also appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with a mighty hand

contextId.information: Moses speaks as if disease were a heavy object that Yahweh would put on top of people. AT: "he will not make you sick with any of the evil diseases ... but he will make your enemies sick with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: none of the evil diseases ... will he put on you, but he will put them on all those who hate you

contextId.information: If the people worship other gods, they will be like an animal caught in a hunter's trap, and they will be unable to escape. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that will be a trap for you

contextId.information: Even taking the gold or silver on the idols could cause the people to start worshiping them. By doing this they would become like an animal caught by a trap. This can be stated in active form. AT: "it will become a trap to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you will become trapped by it

contextId.information: Yahweh cursing something and promising to destroy it is spoken of as if Yahweh were setting the object apart from everything else. This can be stated in active form. AT: "for Yahweh has set it apart for destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: for it is set apart for destruction

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for the time they were slaves in Egypt. AT: "out from the place where you were slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: out of the house of bondage

contextId.information: Walking is a metaphor for obeying. AT: "serve other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walk after other gods

contextId.information: Moses speaks as if obeying God's commands were walking along a path. AT: "They have already disobeyed my commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They have quickly turned aside out of the path that I commanded them

contextId.information: Moses speaks as if Yahweh had rescued the Israelites by paying money to free them from slavery. AT: "you have rescued" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have redeemed

contextId.information: Here "a mighty hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "with your mighty power." Similar words also appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with a mighty hand

contextId.information: The word "foreskin" refers to the fold of skin on a man's private parts that is removed during circumcision. Here Moses is referring to a spiritual circumcision. This means the people must remove the sin from their lives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: circumcise the foreskin of your heart

contextId.information: Here "mighty hand" and "outstretched arm" are metaphors for Yahweh's power. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:34|4:34]]. AT: "or his mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his mighty hand, or his outstretched arm

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. Translate these words as they are in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. AT: "be able to live a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: prolong your days

contextId.information: God becoming angry is spoken of as if it were a fire that were starting. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that Yahweh does not become angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: so that the anger of Yahweh is not kindled against you

contextId.information: A person always thinking about and considering what Moses commands is spoken of as if the heart and soul were a container and Moses's words were the content to fill the container. AT: "be very careful to remember these words that I am saying to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lay up these words of mine in your heart and soul

contextId.information: How Yahweh wants a person to live and behave is spoken of as if they are Yahweh's ways or roads. A person obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if he were walking on Yahweh's ways or roads. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walk in all his ways

contextId.information: To have a good relationship with Yahweh and to completely rely on him is spoken of as if the person were clinging to Yahweh. AT: "to rely on him" or "to have a good relationship with him" Look at how similar words are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:10:20|10:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to cling to him

contextId.information: Yahweh causing the people to be very afraid is spoken of as if fear and terror were an object that he will place on the people. AT: "Yahweh your God will cause the people in every place you go to be very afraid of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh your God will lay the fear of you and the terror of you upon all the land that you tread on

contextId.information: Allowing the people to choose whether they want God to bless them or curse them is spoken of as if a blessing and a curse were objects that Moses is setting in front of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I set before you today a blessing and a curse

contextId.information: The commands of Yahweh that Moses is telling the people are spoken of as if they were God's way or road. To not obey God's commands is spoken of as if people physically were to turn in another direction away from Yahweh to follow other gods. AT: "but stop obeying what I command you today, in order to worship other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but turn aside from the way that I command you today, to go after other gods

contextId.information: God's statutes and decrees, which Moses is telling the people, are spoken of as if they were objects that Moses is setting before the people. AT: "I am giving to you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I set before you

contextId.information: The land that God is giving to the people of Israel is spoken of as if it were a possession that a father leaves as an inheritance for his children. AT: "to the land that Yahweh your God is giving to you as a permanent possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to the inheritance that Yahweh your God is giving you

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the unclean ... persons

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the unclean ... persons

contextId.information: Here the way that blood sustains life is spoken of as if the blood were life itself. AT: "the blood sustains life" or "the blood causes animals and people to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the blood is the life

contextId.information: Yahweh destroying the people groups in Canaan is spoken of as if he were cutting them off, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cuts off the nations

contextId.information: A person learning about and worshiping other gods is spoken of as if they are caught in a hunter's trap. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that you do not act like them ... that you do try to learn about their gods, asking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: that you are not trapped into following them ... trapped into investigating their gods, into asking

contextId.information: Obeying and worshiping Yahweh is spoken of as if the people were walking after or following Yahweh. AT: "You will obey Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will walk after Yahweh your God

contextId.information: To have a good relationship with Yahweh and to completely rely on him is spoken of as if the person were clinging to Yahweh. AT: "rely on him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cling to him

contextId.information: Yahweh rescuing the people of Israel from being slaves in Egypt is spoken of as if Yahweh paid money to redeem his people out of slavery. AT: "who rescued you out of the place where you were slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who redeemed you out of the house of bondage

contextId.information: How God wants a person to live or behave is spoken of as if it were a way or road on which God wants his people to walk. A person trying to cause someone else to stop obeying God is spoken of as if the person were trying to get the other person to stop walking on God's way or road. AT: "make you disobey what Yahweh your God commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: draw you out of the way in which Yahweh your God commanded you to walk

contextId.information: Yahweh cursing something and promising to destroy it is spoken of as if Yahweh were setting the object apart from other things. This can be stated in active form. AT: "You must not keep any of the things God has commanded you to destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: None of those things set apart for destruction must stick in your hand

contextId.information: Yahweh no longer being angry is spoken of as his anger were an object and Yahweh physically turns away from it. AT: "Yahweh will stop being angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will turn from the fierceness of his anger

contextId.information: Yahweh choosing the people of Israel to belong to him in a special way is spoken of as if Yahweh set them apart from all other nations. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh your God has set you apart from other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you are a nation that is set apart to Yahweh your God

contextId.information: Something Yahweh says is unfit for his people to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are unclean for you

contextId.information: Something Yahweh says is unfit for his people to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The pig is unclean for you

contextId.information: Something Yahweh says is unfit for his people to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are unclean for you

contextId.information: An animal that God says is fit for his people to eat is spoken of as if the animal were physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: All clean birds

contextId.information: Animals that God says are unfit for his people to eat are spoken of as if the animals are physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: are unclean for you

contextId.information: Animals that God says are fit for his people to eat are spoken of as if the animals are physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all clean flying things

contextId.information: Yahweh choosing the people of Israel to belong to him in a special way is spoken of as if Yahweh set them apart from all other nations. This can be stated in active form. AT: "For Yahweh your God has set you apart from other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: For you are a nation that is set apart to Yahweh your God

contextId.information: God not giving any land to the Levites is spoken of as if he were not giving them an inheritance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: because he has no portion nor inheritance with you

contextId.information: The land that Yahweh is giving to his people is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that Yahweh is giving them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he gives you as an inheritance to possess

contextId.information: A person who refuses to provide for a poor person is spoken of as if he were shutting his hand so that the poor person cannot get anything from him. AT: "nor refuse to help your fellow Israelite who is poor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: nor shut your hand from your poor brother

contextId.information: Something that will happen soon is spoken of as if it were physically near. AT: "will happen soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is near

contextId.information: A person who has no possessions to provide for himself or his family is spoken of as if his hands were empty. AT: "you must not let him leave without having anything to provide for himself and his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you must not let him go empty-handed

contextId.information: A person who is acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the clean persons

contextId.information: Moses speaks of justice as if it were a physical object that a strong person can violently pull away from a weak person. AT: "You must not be unfair when you judge" This can be stated in positive form. Your language might have one word that means "use force to take away." AT: "You must make just decisions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: You must not take justice away by force

contextId.information: Taking a bribe is spoken of as if the bribe were corrupting the people. AT: "for even a wise man who accepts a bribe will become blind, and even a righteous man who accepts a bribe will tell lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for a bribe blinds the eyes of the wise and perverts the words of the righteous

contextId.information: justice is spoken of as a person who is walking. A person who is doing what is fair and just is spoken of as if he was following close behindjustice. AT: "do only what is fair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: follow after justice, after justice alone

contextId.information: Giving someone the authority to rule as king in Israel is spoken of as if the people were setting the person in a place above them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set a king over myself

contextId.information: The Levites not receiving any land from Yahweh is spoken of as if they would not receive an inheritance. AT: "will not possess any of the people's land" or "will not receive any of the land that the Israelites will possess" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will have no portion nor inheritance with Israel

contextId.information: Moses speaks of the great honor that Aaron and his descendants will have by serving Yahweh as priests as if Yahweh were something that they will inherit. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:10:08|10:9]]. AT: "instead, they will have Yahweh" or "instead, Yahweh will allow them to serve him and he will provide for them through that service" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh is their inheritance

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing a person to be a prophet is spoken of as if Yahweh would raise or lift the person up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh your God will raise up for you a prophet

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing a person to be a prophet is spoken of as if Yahweh would raise or lift the person up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will raise up a prophet for them

contextId.information: Yahweh telling the prophet what to say is spoken of as if Yahweh would put words in the prophet's mouth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will put my words in his mouth

contextId.information: Yahweh destroying the people who live in Canaan is spoken of as if he were cutting them off, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When Yahweh your God cuts off the nations

contextId.information: Yahweh giving the land to the people of Israel is spoken of as if the people are inheriting the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the land that Yahweh your God is causing you to inherit

contextId.information: Someone being very angry is spoken of as if anger were something that could become hot. AT: "and being very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the heat of his anger

contextId.information: How God wants a person to live or behave is spoken of as if it were Yahweh's way or road. A person who obeys Yahweh is spoken of as if he were walking on Yahweh's way or road. AT: "to always obey him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to always walk in his ways

contextId.information: The land that Yahweh is giving the people of Israel is spoken of as if it were an inheritance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh your God is giving you for as an inheritance

contextId.information: The people of Israel being guilty for a person dying because they did not build a city where he would be safe from the "blood avenger" is spoken of as if the guilt of his death is on them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that no bloodguilt may be on you

contextId.information: Yahweh giving the land to the people of Israel is spoken of as if they were inheriting the land. AT: "in the land that Yahweh your God is giving to you to possess" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in your inheritance that you will inherit, in the land that Yahweh your God is giving you to possess

contextId.information: Yahweh defeating the enemies of the people of Israel is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who would fight along with the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh your God is the one who is going with you to fight for you against your enemies

contextId.information: The cities in Canaan that Yahweh is giving to the people is spoken of as if the cities were the people's inheritance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In the cities of these peoples that Yahweh your God is giving you as an inheritance

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. AT: "be able to live a long time." Translate these words as they are in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: prolong your days

contextId.information: Moses speaks of justice as if it were a physical object that a stronger person can violently pull away from a weaker person. AT: "You must not treat a foreigner or the fatherless unfairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You must not use force to take away the justice that is due the foreigner or the fatherless

contextId.information: Yahweh choosing the people of Israel to belong to him in a special way is spoken of as if Yahweh set them apart from all other nations. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh your God will set you apart from other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: You will be a people that is set apart to Yahweh your God

contextId.information: Moses speaks of justice as if it were a physical object that a stronger person can violently pull away from a weaker person. Your language might have one word that means "use force to take away." Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:24:17|24:17]]. AT: "treats a foreigner ... widow unfairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: uses force to take away the justice due to a foreigner ... widow

contextId.information: Moses speaks of being important or being great as if it were being physically higher, as on a higher hill. AT: "make you more important than" or "make you greater than"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set you above

contextId.information: Moses describes the blessings as a person who would attack them by surprise or chase and catch them. AT: "Yahweh will bless you like this in ways that will completely surprise you, and it will be as if you cannot escape having him bless you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: All these blessings will come on you and overtake you

contextId.information: Moses describes Yahweh blessing the Israelites as if Yahweh were commanding a person to attack them by surprise. AT: "When Yahweh blesses you, you will be surprised by how much grain you have in your barns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will command the blessing to come on you in your barns

contextId.information: Yahweh choosing the people of Israel to belong to him in a special way is spoken of as if Yahweh put them in a place different from the place all other nations live in. AT: "Yahweh will make you a holy people that belongs to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will establish you as a people that is set apart for himself

contextId.information: Moses speaks of the clouds from which the rain falls as if they were a building where he stores the rain. AT: "the clouds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his storehouse of the heavens

contextId.information: This metaphor describes the nation of Israel as an animal and means the Israelites will always be the leaders over other nations and never the servants following behind them. The Israelites will be superior in power, money, and honor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the head, and not the tail

contextId.information: Disobeying Yahweh and worshiping other gods is spoken of as if a person physically turned and went in a different direction from Yahweh's words. AT: "if you do not disobey what I am commanding you today by serving other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if you do not turn away from any of the words that I am commanding you today, to the right hand or to the left, so as to go after other gods to serve them

contextId.information: Moses describes the curses as a person who would attack them by surprise or chase and catch them. AT: "Yahweh will curse you like this in ways that will completely surprise you, and it will be as if you cannot escape having him curse you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: then all these curses will come on you and overtake you

contextId.information: Moses speaks of the earth being like iron because no crops will grow. AT: "nothing will grow from the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the earth ... will be iron

contextId.information: This means foreigners will have more power and authority than the Israelites. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:28:13|28:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will be the head, and you will be the tail

contextId.information: Moses describes the curses as a person who would attack them by surprise or chase and catch them. See how you translated something similar in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:28:01|28:2]]. AT: "Yahweh will curse you like this in ways that will completely surprise you, and it will be as if he is chasing you and you cannot escape having him curse you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: All these curses will come on you and will pursue and overtake you until you are destroyed

contextId.information: Here "the flesh of your sons and of your daughters" explains the metaphor "the fruit of your own body." The people will be so hungry after the enemy army surrounds their city that they will eat their own children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of your own body, the flesh of your sons and of your daughters

contextId.information: Moses uses a metaphor to speak of the people as though they were fruit that Yahweh would take off a bush. This can be stated in active form. AT: "He will remove you from the land which you are entering to possess" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: You will be plucked off the land that you are going into to possess

contextId.information: Moses speaks of someone who secretly worships another God as if he were a root, and the evil deeds he does to serve that god, and which he encourages others to do, as a bitter plant that poisons people. AT: "any person who worships idols and causes others to disobey Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: any root that produces gall and wormwood

contextId.information: Here the words "wet" and "dry" are metaphors for the righteous people and the wicked people. This forms a merism for "everyone." AT: "This would cause Yahweh to destroy both the righteous people and the wicked people in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: This would destroy the wet together with the dry

contextId.information: Moses compares Yahweh being angry to someone starting a fire. This emphasizes God's power to destroy whatever makes him angry, and it can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh has became very angry with this land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the anger of Yahweh has been kindled against this land

contextId.information: Israel is compared to a bad plant that Yahweh has pulled up and thrown out of a garden. AT: "Yahweh has removed them from their land ... and has forced them to go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has uprooted them from their land ... and has thrown them

contextId.information: Moses speaks of curses as though they were a load or a cover that someone could physically put on top of a person. AT: "will cause your enemies to suffer from these curses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will put all these curses on your enemies

contextId.information: Moses speaks of being able to understand what a commandment requires a person to do as if it were that person being able to reach a physical object. AT: "neither is it too difficult for you to understand what Yahweh requires you to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: neither is it too far for you to reach

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. AT: "be able to live a long time." Translate these words as they are in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: prolong your days

contextId.information: Yahweh compares his anger to someone starting a fire. This emphasizes God's power to destroy whatever makes him angry. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will kindle my anger against them" or "I will become angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: my anger will be kindled against them

contextId.information: This a proper name that Moses gives to Yahweh, who, like a rock, is strong and able to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The Rock

contextId.information: This is like a mother giving her breast to an infant. "allowed him to suck honey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: nourished him with honey

contextId.information: This means Yahweh is strong like a rock and able to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Rock of his salvation

contextId.information: This a proper name that Moses gives to Yahweh, who, like a rock, is strong and able to protect his people. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:03|32:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Rock

contextId.information: Here Yahweh is called the rock because he is strong and protective. AT: "You have left the protective care of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have deserted the Rock

contextId.information: This a proper name that Moses gives to Yahweh, who, like a rock, is strong and able to protect his people. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:03|32:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Rock

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of bad things that would happen to the Israelites as if they were something like dirt that he could pile up on top of the Israelites. AT: "I will make sure that many bad things happen to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will heap disasters on them

contextId.information: Moses compares enemies who worship false gods to the wicked people who lived in Sodom and Gomorrah and to grapevines that produce poisonous fruit. This means their enemies are wicked and will cause the Israelites to die if the Israelites start to act like the people who live around them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For their vine comes from the vine of Sodom ... clusters are bitter

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the bad things that will happen to his enemies as if the bad things were people running eagerly to punish them. AT: "and I will punish them quickly" (See UDB)  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and the things that are to come on them will hurry to happen

contextId.information: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. AT: "be able to live a long time." Translate these words as they are in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: prolong your days

contextId.information: This phrase is used twice as a metaphor. AT: "rise up to fight ... cause any more trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rise up ... rise up

contextId.information: This metaphor is of a man putting his hand on the head of a son and asking God to bless the son. The man here is Yahweh. AT: "May Yahweh bless Joseph as a father blesses his son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let the blessing come on the head of Joseph

contextId.information: The Hebrew word translated "suck" here refers to how a baby nurses at its mother's breast. It means the people will gain wealth from the sea like a baby gets milk from its mother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For they will suck the abundance of the seas

contextId.information: The dew is spoken of as being so much that it is as if it were raining. Possible meanings are 1) Moses is blessing Israel, "may much dew cover the land like rain" or 2) Moses is telling what will happen in the future, "much dew will cover the land like rain." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let his heavens drop dew

contextId.information: The word "shield" is a metaphor for Yahweh protecting and defending the Israelites. The abstract noun "help" can be translated as a verb. AT: "the one who protects you and helps you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the shield of your help

contextId.information: The writer speaks as if Joshua were a container and the spirit were a physical object that could be put into a container. AT: "Yahweh enabled Joshua ... to be very wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Joshua ... was full of the spirit of wisdom
